Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way at (517)-243-9743
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/1/25, a staff member brought a youth back into the facility in
a rough manner (information first reported). On 4/1/25 or 4/2/25, a
staff member dragged a youth by the hood and threw the youth
into a closet and four windows. Two other staff were present and
witnessed the incident (additional information called in).
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on April 2, 2025,
and reported they had no additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 4,
2025, by this consultant and again on April 9, 2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker and Officer. Youth A
described being out of bounds from the agency, and Supervisor 1
and Staff 1 escorted him back to the facility. Youth A reported he
fell and Supervisor 1 dragged Youth A on his back by the collar of
his hoodie while on the ground back to the facility. Youth A stated
when they [Supervisor 1, Staff 1 and Youth A] were back at the
facility, Supervisor 1 threw Youth A into three different outside
windows. Youth A stated Staff 1 witnessed Supervisor 1’s actions
but did not intervene. Youth A described Supervisor 1 pushing
Youth A through the front door, into the facility so Youth A started
to punch Supervisor 1 in his arm because Supervisor 1 was
scaring him. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 was inside the facility
and saw Supervisor 1 drag and push Youth A into one of the
windows outside. Youth A stated he received a scratch on his
back and Supervisor 2 took a picture of the scratch. Youth A
reported after Supervisor 1 pushed him into the facility, Supervisor
1 placed his arm on Youth A’s neck area and pushed him to the
floor. Youth A stated Supervisor 2 and Youth C may have
witnessed Supervisor 1 pushing Youth A to the floor. Youth A
denied any other youth being outside when he was being dragged
and/or pushed into the windows by Supervisor 1.
2

Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
April 9, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker and Officer.
Supervisor 1 described responding to an extra call from Staff 1 for
Youth A being out of bounds. Supervisor 1 reported seeing Youth
A come out of the woods and verbally asking Youth A to return to
the house. Supervisor 1 stated he started to escort Youth A back
to the house with Staff 1, but Youth A continued to drop to the
ground. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A would stand back up and
kick and spit at Staff 1. Supervisor 1 described Staff 1 tripping
and falling so Supervisor 1 escorted Youth A back to the house
while Staff 1 walked behind. Supervisor 1 stated he was holding
Youth A by the arm and the shoulder during the escort.
Supervisor 1 reported once they [Supervisor 1, Staff 1 and Youth
A] were back at the facility they stopped at the front door and Staff
1 opened the front door. Supervisor 1 reported he “released”
Youth A. Supervisor 1 demonstrated what this looked like and
showed that both of his hands were placed on Youth A’s
shoulders and “released” Youth A into the facility. Supervisor 1
stated the release was, “a little more than needed” and admitted to
being frustrated. Supervisor 1 reported that this is not how staff
are trained to “release” youth.
Supervisor 1 denied pushing Youth A into any window or closet.
Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was using both of his hands
grabbing Supervisor 1’s clothes on his chest and Supervisor 1
asked Youth A to let go. Supervisor 1 described using his hand to
block Youth A from spitting on him. Supervisor 1 reported his
hand hoovered over Youth A’s mouth to block the spit but denied
ever touching Youth A’s face, neck or throat. Supervisor 1 denied
pushing Youth A to the floor. Supervisor 1 denied dragging Youth
A with his hoodie while outside. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A
did not report he was hurt.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 9,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker and Officer. Staff 1
described Youth A leaving the facility, running through the brush
and Supervisor 1 coming to assist with Youth A while Staff 1 was
following Youth A. Staff 1 reported they escorted Youth A back to
the facility. Staff 1 described being on one side of Youth A holding
one of Youth A’s arms and Supervisor 1 being on the other side of
Youth A holding Youth A’s other arm walking back to the facility.
Staff 1 stated Youth A was resisting and kept dropping his weight.
Staff 1 reported falling during the escort, so Supervisor 1
continued the escort as Staff 1 followed behind. Staff 1 described
Supervisor 1 dragging Youth A by Youth A’s hoodie. Staff 1
stated Supervisor 1 dragged Youth A on his back by the collar of
3

his hoodie while on the ground and it “basically was not right.”
Staff 1 denied this being the proper technique for an escort. Staff
1 reported when they [Supervisor 1, Youth A and Staff 1] arrived
at the facility, Supervisor 1 “chucked” [Youth A] against the wall
under the window, roughly.” Staff 1 demonstrated what this meant
by throwing his water bottle against the wall. Supervisor 1 stated it
was the window to the left of the front entrance door. Staff 1
reported Youth A hit the wall. Staff 1 stated Supervisor 2 was
inside the facility and assisted in getting Youth A inside the facility
and deescalating him. Staff 1 reported Supervisor 1 was asked to
leave and Staff 1 went to use the restroom. Staff 1 stated Youth A
reported having pain in his back and had about a two-inch scratch.
Staff 1 reported the scratch could have come from Youth A being
thrown into the wall by Supervisor 1. Staff 1 denied ever seeing
Supervisor 1 have this type of interaction with youth prior to this
event. Staff 1 denied observing Supervisor 1 choke Youth A.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
April 9, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker and Officer.
Supervisor 2 described Youth A going out of bounds, Staff 1
following Youth A and Supervisor 2 calling Supervisor 1 for
assistance. Supervisor 2 reported staying in the facility with the
other youth. Supervisor 2 described doing room checks and from
the window seeing Supervisor 1 dragging Youth A on his back by
the collar of his hoodie while on the ground. Supervisor 2 reported
coming to the front of the house and from the window, seeing
Supervisor 1 push Youth A into the window to the right of the
entrance door (on the right from the inside). Supervisor 2 reported
she opened the door and Supervisor 1 pushed Youth A into the
facility. Supervisor 2 stated Supervisor 1 grabbed Youth A by the
face and pushed Youth A down to the floor. Supervisor 2 reported
she intervened, and Youth A went to his room to calm down.
Supervisor 2 described Supervisor 1 saying, “get his [Youth A]
shoes off or I’ll drag them off.” Supervisor 2 reported about 30
minutes later Youth A stated his back hurt. Supervisor 2 stated
Youth A’s back was bleeding a little bit and observed a scratch
mark. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A did not report any other pain
on his body. Supervisor 2 denied seeing Youth A spit at
Supervisor 1. Supervisor 2 denied ever seeing Supervisor 1 have
this type of interaction with youth prior to this event. Supervisor 2
denied seeing Supervisor 1 choke Youth A.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 9,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B reported he
could not recall seeing Supervisor 1 drag or push Youth A or any
4

other youth at the facility. Youth B stated he could not recall any
interactions between Supervisor 1 and Youth A.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on April 9,
2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth C reported
from the window inside he saw Supervisor 1 dragging Youth A on
his back by the collar of his hoodie while on the ground. Youth C
reported Staff 1 was walking behind Supervisor 2 and Youth A.
Youth C stated while still outside, Supervisor 1 pushed Youth A
into the window by the front entrance door. Youth C reported
Supervisor 1 pushed Youth A into the facility and placed his hand
around Youth A’s neck and slammed Youth A to the ground.
Youth C reported Supervisor 2 and Staff 1 were also in the facility
when this occurred. Youth C stated he saw a mark on Youth A’s
neck and a scratch on his back. Youth C denied ever seeing
other youth treated this way by Supervisor 1 or any other staff.
Video Review
Video footage of 4/01/2025 was reviewed on 4/4/25 and again on
4/9/2025 with DHHS Worker and Officer. There is no video
outside of the house. The video shows Supervisor 2 walking
toward the front entrance door, the door opened, and Supervisor 1
pushed Youth A into the facility. Youth A stumbles forward, turns
around toward Supervisor 1 and attempts to punch Supervisor 1.
Supervisor 2 is seen trying to get between Supervisor 1 and Youth
A. Supervisor 1 places his right hand on the side of Youth A’s
face and pushes Youth A to the floor. Youth A is pushed to the
floor, Supervisor 2 continues attempting to get between
Supervisor 1 and Youth A then Supervisor 1 backs away. Youth A
stands up and moves toward Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 gets
in front of Youth A stopping him from reaching Supervisor 1. Staff
1 and Youth B are also seen on camera but are not involved in the
incident. Youth A is seen walking toward his bedroom, entering
his room and Supervisor 1 leaves the area.
Documents Reviewed:
• Safety Plan for Supervisor 1. Safety Plan states, “This
email is a follow up to the conversation that we had today
(4/2/25). Due to the incident which occurred on 4/1/25 at
Hainley House, you are being placed on a safety plan
which includes to not be alone with youth. You are also to
not respond to issues involving the youth [Youth A]. We
will be conducting an investigation and will update you with
information as I have it.”
• Supervisor 1’s personnel file: There was one disciplinary
action form dated 07/09/23 not related to interactions with
5

youth. Supervisor 1 completed the required Aegis training
on 12/12/2024.
• Emails from Supervisor 2 and Staff 1 to Director of
Residential dated 04/01/2025 describing the incident
between Supervisor 1 and Youth A. The emails were
consistent with Supervisor 2 and Staff 1’s interviews.
• Eagle Village Behavior Support and Management. Policy
states, “Behavior support and management is more than
just managing the youths’ physical behavior; it involves the
entire treatment process to the end of helping the youth
manage their own behavior in a socially healthy and
respectful manner. Any staff member found using
unacceptable discipline practices will immediately be
subject to disciplinary action up to termination.”
• Eagle Village Therapeutic Holds Policy. Policy states, Only
those techniques taught during Aegis training are
permitted. These include the Voluntary Escort, Level One,
Level Two, Level Three, Level 4, the Benevolent Restraint,
and the Aegis Safety Position.”
• Eagle Village Behavior Plans; Abuse or Neglect of Client(s)
Policy. Policy states, “It is Eagle Village policy that physical
abuse is never accepted in any manner as an interaction
between staff and clients. Examples of physical abuse
could be, but are not limited to: paddling, spanking, hitting,
slapping, kicking, hair pulling, throwing, severe shaking,
inappropriate touching with an object, or an inappropriate
therapeutic hold.”
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as per Supervisor 2, Staff 1,
Youth A and Youth C’s interviews, along with video review
Supervisor 1 pushed Youth A into the facility and placed his hand
on Youth A’s chin and neck pushing Youth A to the ground.
Youth A reported and Staff 1, Supervisor 2, Youth C described
seeing Supervisor 1 drag Youth A by his hoodie toward the facility.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law;
Section development of plan required.
Description (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, CL
722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility did not have the direct staff who witnessed the
interaction between Supervisor 1 and Youth A report the incident
6

to Centralized Intake. The incident that was reported lacked
details of the entire interaction between Supervisor 1 and Youth A.
Investigation Director of Residential was interviewed via telephone on April
11, 2025. Director of Residential reported not reading the emails
sent by Supervisor 2 and Staff 1 until the following day. Director of
Residential stated when Supervisor 2 called she [Supervisor 2]
reported Supervisor 1 roughly brought Youth A into the facility.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
April 9, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker and Officer
and again on May 7, 2025, by this consultant. Supervisor 2
reported she called Director of Residential right after the incident
between Supervisor 1 and Youth A to report what happened.
Supervisor 2 stated she told Director of Residential everything
Supervisor 2 described in the interview with DHHS Worker, Officer
and this consultant. During the interview on May 7, 2025,
Supervisor 2 reported she gave most of the details of what
happened between Supervisor 1 and Youth A over the phone to
Director of Residential. Supervisor 2 confirmed she did not report
the allegations into centralized intake.
Documents Reviewed:
• Emails from Supervisor 2 at 9:33pm and Staff 1 at 10:29pm
to Director of Residential dated 04/01/2025 describing
incident between Supervisor 1 and Youth A. The emails
were time stamped after Complainant reported the
allegations. The information in the emails did not match the
original allegations reported. The emails were consistent
with Supervisor 2 and Staff 1’s interviews.
• Eagle Village Reporting Neglect and Abuse Policy. Policy
states, “All reports of suspected child neglect or abuse
must be immediately reported to the On Call Supervisor
who will report to the On Call Administrator. Eagle Village
administration will work with the reporter to submit incidents
of suspected physical abuse, sexual abuse, or neglect of a
youth in placement.”
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as the known information
and details of the suspected abuse/neglect were not accurately
reported. The facility failed to have Supervisor 2 directly report
the concerns of suspected abuse/neglect.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was provided in regards to changing the
reporting of child abuse and neglect policy to state all suspected
7

abuse or neglect will immediately be reported to centralized intake
by the direct observer.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
